description: Register and corpus-informed usage: how English differs across conversation, news, fiction, academic prose, and professional writing.

topics.name: Register Differences (High-Level)
coreClaims: Academic prose tends to compress information (nominalizations, dense noun phrases).
Conversation tends to be interactive (pronouns, stance markers, ellipsis, discourse particles).
practice: Convert conversational phrasing into academic register while preserving meaning.
Spot register-inappropriate forms (not errors, but mismatches).

topics.name: Frequency-Driven Reasoning
coreClaims: When multiple grammatical options exist, distribution by register helps decide which to use.
A usage decision can be supported by: (a) register expectations, (b) clarity goals, (c) audience norms.
practice: Write a brief 'usage justification' note for one contested form (e.g., passive voice in methods sections).

topics.name: Usage Diagnostic Workflow
coreClaims: High-performing students treat usage as a debugging task: identify pattern → consult reference → test in context.
Error logs work best when grouped by pattern (articles, prepositions, complement frames).
practice: Maintain a 20-item error log with: pattern, example, correction, rule-of-thumb, register note.
